questions.question: What is an IP datagram?
questions.option_a: A unit of data at the Transport layer
questions.option_b: A unit of data at the Network layer
questions.option_c: A unit of data at the Data link layer
questions.option_d: A unit of data at the Application layer

questions.question: Which class of IP addresses is used for experimental purposes?
What is the maximum value for the Time To Live (TTL) field in an IP header?
Which of the following is a private IP address range?
What is the primary function of the Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP)?
questions.option_a: To provide encryption for IP packets
questions.option_c: To send error and control messages

questions.question: Which IPv4 address is used for the loopback test?
What is the purpose of the Total Length field in an IP header?
questions.option_a: To specify the length of the IP header only
questions.option_b: To specify the length of the IP header and data
questions.option_c: To specify the length of the data link layer frame
questions.option_d: To specify the length of the MAC address

questions.question: What is a subnet?
questions.option_a: A method to divide an IP address into multiple IP addresses
questions.option_b: A method to create virtual networks

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of the network layer?
What is the difference between IPv4 and IPv6 addresses?
questions.option_a: IPv4 uses 64-bit addresses; IPv6 uses 128-bit addresses
questions.option_b: IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses; IPv6 uses 64-bit addresses
questions.option_c: IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses; IPv6 uses 128-bit addresses
questions.option_d: IPv4 uses 128-bit addresses; IPv6 uses 256-bit addresses

questions.question: Which IP address class is reserved for multicast?
What is the purpose of the IP header checksum?
questions.option_a: To provide error detection for the entire IP packet
questions.option_b: To provide error detection for the IP header only
questions.option_c: To provide error correction for the IP header
questions.option_d: To provide error correction for the entire IP packet

questions.question: Which IP address class provides the least number of host addresses?
What does the term "fragmentation" refer to in networking?
questions.option_b: Dividing a large packet into smaller fragments
questions.option_d: Forwarding packets to the correct destination

questions.question: Which field in an IP header determines the path a packet should take?
What is the range of IP addresses in a Class B network?
What is the purpose of the "Options" field in an IP header?
questions.option_b: To specify optional settings for the packet
questions.option_c: To define the total length of the packet
questions.option_d: To indicate the type of service

questions.question: What does the acronym "ARP" stand for in networking?
What is the default subnet mask for a Class A IP address?
Which IP address is reserved for local communications within a private network?
What is the function of the "Type of Service" (TOS) field in an IP header?
questions.option_a: To indicate the type of upper-layer protocol
questions.option_b: To specify the quality of service desired

questions.question: Which IP address is used to refer to the local machine?
Which class of IP address is typically used for small to medium-sized networks?
What is the role of the "Fragment Offset" field in an IP header?
questions.option_a: To specify the length of the datagram
questions.option_c: To indicate the position of the fragment in the original datagram
questions.option_d: To set the priority of the datagram

questions.question: Which address is considered a private IP address?
What is the purpose of Network Address Translation (NAT)?
questions.option_c: To convert private IP addresses to a public IP address
questions.option_d: To route data packets between networks

questions.question: Which IP address is reserved for future use?
What is the main advantage of using CIDR in IP addressing?
questions.option_b: Reduced number of available IP addresses

questions.question: Which protocol operates at the Network layer of the OSI model?
What is the purpose of the "More Fragments" flag in an IP header?
questions.option_b: To indicate more fragments are following

questions.question: Which address is a broadcast address for the local network?
What is the purpose of the "Identification" field in an IP header?
What is a characteristic of the IPv4 protocol?
Which IP address is used for private network communication?
What is the purpose of the "Version" field in an IP header?
Which address is reserved for multicast communication?
What is the function of the "Header Length" field in an IP header?
questions.option_a: To specify the length of the data
questions.option_b: To specify the length of the IP header

questions.question: What is the primary function of the network layer?
questions.option_c: To determine the best path for data transmission

questions.question: What is the main purpose of internetworking?
questions.option_a: To connect two or more networks to create a larger network
questions.option_b: To manage internal network traffic only
questions.explanation: Internetworking means connecting two or more networks to create a larger network, enabling communication between different networks.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes an intranet?
questions.option_a: A public network accessible to everyone
questions.option_b: A private network belonging to a single organization
questions.explanation: An intranet is a private network that belongs to a single organization and is accessible only by the organization's members or authorized users.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of an extranet?
questions.option_a: To provide public access to all network resources
questions.option_b: To restrict access to internal users only
questions.option_c: To provide secure access to authorized external users
questions.explanation: An extranet provides secure and safe access to individuals who work for different organizations but require access to the organization's data.

questions.question: At which OSI layer does internetworking occur?
questions.explanation: Interconnection of IP networks happens at Layer 3 (Network layer), using routers.

questions.question: What is a socket in the context of networking?
questions.option_b: An endpoint for sending or receiving data across a network
questions.explanation: A socket is an endpoint for sending or receiving data across a network and is created by application layer processes.

questions.question: What is the range of valid port numbers in TCP/IP?
questions.explanation: Port numbers are specified using 16 bits, allowing for a range from 0 to 65535.

questions.question: What is the main difference between TCP and UDP?
questions.option_b: UDP provides reliable, ordered delivery while TCP doesn't
questions.option_c: TCP provides reliable, ordered delivery while UDP doesn't
questions.option_d: TCP uses smaller headers than UDP
questions.explanation: TCP provides reliable, in-order delivery with connection setup and flow control, while UDP provides unreliable, unordered delivery.

questions.question: What is multiplexing in the transport layer?
questions.option_c: Handling data from multiple sockets and adding transport headers
questions.explanation: Multiplexing at the transport layer involves handling data from multiple sockets and adding transport headers that will be used for demultiplexing.

questions.question: In TCP, what is the purpose of the three-way handshake?
questions.option_b: To establish connection and agree on parameters
questions.explanation: The three-way handshake is used to establish a connection and agree on connection parameters like starting sequence numbers and receive buffer sizes.

questions.question: What is flow control in TCP?
questions.option_a: Controlling the direction of data flow
questions.option_b: Preventing the sender from overwhelming the receiver
questions.explanation: Flow control ensures that the sender doesn't overflow the receiver's buffer by sending too much data too fast.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the TCP window size?
questions.option_c: To indicate how much data the receiver can accept
questions.explanation: The TCP window size (rwnd) indicates the amount of free buffer space the receiver has available to accept incoming data.

questions.question: What triggers a TCP fast retransmit?
questions.explanation: TCP fast retransmit is triggered when the sender receives three duplicate ACKs for the same data, indicating likely segment loss.

questions.question: How does TCP handle acknowledgments?
questions.explanation: TCP uses cumulative acknowledgments, where the receiver acknowledges the last byte received in order.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of UDP?
questions.explanation: UDP is a 'no frills' protocol that provides best-effort delivery without connection establishment or reliability guarantees.

questions.question: In TCP, what is the purpose of the SYN flag?
questions.explanation: The SYN flag is used to synchronize sequence numbers during connection establishment.

questions.question: What determines TCP demultiplexing at the receiver?
questions.option_d: Four-tuple of source/destination IP addresses and port numbers
questions.explanation: TCP uses a four-tuple consisting of source IP, source port, destination IP, and destination port for demultiplexing.

questions.question: What is an autonomous system in networking?
questions.option_b: A group of networks under single administrative control
questions.explanation: An autonomous system is a group of networks and routers controlled by a single administrative entity.

questions.question: What is the difference between interior and exterior gateway protocols?
questions.option_a: Interior protocols are faster than exterior protocols
questions.option_b: Interior protocols work within an AS, exterior protocols work between ASs
questions.option_c: Interior protocols are less secure than exterior protocols
questions.option_d: Interior protocols use different packet formats
questions.explanation: Interior gateway protocols are used for routing within an autonomous system, while exterior gateway protocols are used for routing between autonomous systems.

questions.question: What is the purpose of TCP retransmission timeout?
questions.explanation: TCP retransmission timeout is used to recover from lost segments by resending them if no acknowledgment is received within the timeout period.

questions.question: How does TCP calculate RTT estimates?
questions.option_b: Using the last measured RTT only
questions.option_c: Using an exponential weighted moving average
questions.explanation: TCP uses an exponential weighted moving average (EWMA) to estimate RTT, combining past estimates with new measurements.

questions.question: What is the key difference between distance vector and link state routing protocols?
questions.option_b: Distance vector protocols share complete topology information
questions.option_c: Link state protocols only work with TCP
questions.option_d: Link state protocols share complete topology information
questions.explanation: Link state protocols share complete topology information, while distance vector protocols only share distance information with neighbors.
